I do like this video, but their are some issues here. Vertebrates are not a a step ladder to humans. Instead, vertebrates are a branching tree, with many different groups, and the names are hierarchical not distinct branches. You are, for instance, a derived Agnathan lineage, meaning you evolved from a lineage of jawless fish at some point. Therefore, Aganatha should include all vertebrates that share a common ancestor with lampreys (and hagfish, now united in one group).  Mammals are complex, but they are certainly no more complex than birds and arguably any other group. Birds are reptiles, as are mammals, and all are very derived amphibian lineages. The Aves group is also all but gone now, and should be replaced by the correct class: Dinosauria. Finally, Archosaurs are absolutely not the most ancient reptile group, they are one of the most derived reptile groups, the opposite of the video's assertion.

He refers to mammals as a group as 'the most complex phylum'.   Basically, are the traits that characterise modern mammals more complex than those than characterise modern birds?   Picking a specific mammal or a specific bird isn't really the point, as I'm referring to traits all mammals and all birds share.
Merry Machiavelli Mammals tend to be much smarter than birds with far more efficient nerves and oxygen regulation.  Not always, but generally.

Kumquatodor I'm not sure the oxygen thing is true. In mammalian lungs, Oxygen and CO2 mix internally as we're breathing, This decreases Oxygen concentration and thus makes breathing less efficient. .  In avian lungs, however, it's a one-track system. This means that the Oxygen we need and the CO2 we expel don't mix.   At least, I believe that is how it works. I'm certainly not an authority on comparative anatomy.   I've never heard the nerve thing though, what do you mean? Do mammals have quicker reaction times for something?

Merry Machiavelli About Oxygen: We are much bigger (and therefore require more). And, though, they mix, the chemicals don't poison us. It's complex in that manner.  We have much faster reflexes. Our twitch muscles allow for much quicker burst of movement. Dogs and cats can pounce so very quickly. Birds have fewer of these muscles. They aren't slow, but they are nowhere near as fast overall as an ape in quick movements.  Apes can also answer questions faster than humans; they could press a button when prompted 5x quicker than you and I. This is faster than birds by far.  This is a mixture of muscles and nerves that make mammals so darn quick.

Kumquatodor Okay, I'll accept you point about nerves :)  But that's not what I meant in regards to Oxygen. CO2 doesn't poison us, it's just that it means the concentration of Oxygen is lower in the lungs. If the concentration of oxygen is lower, then it means the concentration gradient is less steep. This means oxygen diffuses into the bloodstream slower.   Birds evolved to cope with flying at high altitudes, where the air is thinner. It makes sense that they would have a more efficient method of extracting oxygen.   There are other things as well. The honeycomb structure of bird bones is far lighter than mammalian bones, yet almost as strong. This is part of what makes birds light enough to fly.   Bird feathers are widely regarded as one the most complex structures in nature, with the way the quills interlock at a semi-microscopic level. They have all kinds of properties that put fur, scales, and skin to shame.   I would say birds and mammals are roughly equally matched. It's just difficult to way which is more 'complex' when most avian adaptations focus around a very specific end-goal; enabling flight.
Merry Machiavelli You make good arguments. I had a response to the oxygen thing, but refuting one point would not be enough. :). Especially considering I forgot what point I was going to make.

Mammals consist of three lineages. These arose after mammalia split from the sauropsids (common ancestors of birds and reptiles) and exhibit different degrees of complexity. The oldest surviving mammalian lineage is the monotremes - the egg-laying mammals - arose ~210 million years ago. Next we have the marsupials - pouched mammals - and the placentals - us and mice etc - appearing ~167million years ago. As the oldest lineage, monotrema retains the most ancestral (bird/reptile like) traits: egg laying, no teeth, a single hole for reproduction and excrement (the cloaca), reptilian hip and rib structure, lower body temperature (monotremes are 32 degrees compared to 37-39 in other mammals) but have mammalian adaptations including lactation and fur.. the marsupials have developed viviparity - live birth - but give birth to small under-developed young because they lack a true placenta. Marsupials also retain the cloaca. Marsupials and placentals have developed nipples, which are lacking from monotremes. The placental mammals have separate openings for excrement and reproduction, have viviparity, have a true placenta and improved umbilical chord which protects the foetus from the mother's immune system and so allows birth of large and well-developed young. All mammalian lineage have more complex immune systems than birds , with more diversity of immunoglobulin (anti-body) genes. The placental and marsupial, but not the monotreme, lineages have another kind of complexity that has arisen called genetic imprinting. This is like punctuation being added to DNA during the formation of sperm and egg. It doesnt change the sequence of the DNA, but it lets the genes retain information about which parent they came from. The effect is that a gene can be expressed differently depending on which parent it comes from. which is awesome and imposes non-Mendelian attributes.. yeah mammals are more complex :)

Kumquatodor I'm not sure about that Kumquatodor, the Avian respiration system seems to be far more efficient than the Mammalian as Machiavelli pointed out.  Bird intelligence is also not to be snuffed at, obviously birds can't compete with Humans but Parrots and Corvids are way more intelligent than is often assumed, the New Caledonian Crow for example has amazing mental capacity for something its size and really does seem to be at the level of the higher Apes, it is the only Non-primate creature known that creates and modifies tools, often without any previous experience with the tool or the problem presented. In fish (2 chambers) and reptiles (3 chambers), there is a mixture of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood sent throughout the body. And that's okay for smaller organisms. But that's not good enough for mammals. We need blood sent throughout our body to be fully oxygenated! Thus evolved the 4-chambered heart. It allows for the full separation of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood, so that all the blood that goes out to your body is only oxygenated, allowing your body sufficient energy to function!!!
